description: From Middle English noysaunce, from Anglo-Norman nusaunce, nussance and Old French nuisance, from nuisir (“to harm”), from Latin noceō (“to harm”).

examples: The neighbor's dog barking throughout the night is a right nuisance - I'm going to complain.

entries.meaning: A person or thing causing annoyance or inconvenience.
examples: You can be such a nuisance when you don't get your way.

entries.meaning: (law) Anything harmful or offensive to the community or to a member of it, for which a legal remedy exists.
